description: Dive into "Capturing Milan: Iconic Photo Adventures" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capturing Milan: Iconic Photo Adventures

places.generalDescription: Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is a renowned 19th-century glass-covered arcade in Milan, Italy. It's situated at the heart of the city, connecting Piazza del Duomo and Piazza della Scala. The gallery is a major attraction for tourists due to its proximity to significant landmarks like the Cathedral (Duomo) and the opera theatre.

sources.snippet: After visiting the famous Milan Cathedral, it‚Äôs only a one-minute walk to stop by Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II. One of the significant landmarks in the city, this shopping center was designed and built during the 1860s. Between the glass-vaulted arcades and the beautiful luxury shops, the Galleria is a lovely place to pass the time during your stay in Milan. Whether you stop for a cappuccino, to shop, or even just pass through the  Galleria on your way to another district of Milan, it‚Äôs definitely worth stopping to take a photo or two (or maybe 100!).
sources.shortName: The Most Photo Worthy Spots in Milan, Italy

sources.snippet: There‚Äôs hardly a list you can make relating to Milan that wouldn‚Äôt have to include the Galleria. No matter the subject, this place deserves to be on it ‚Äì save for if you‚Äôre collecting ugly places or places no one knows about, both very possible in Milan, though that is a topic for another day. Come here to get pictures of the famous glass ceiling, the shops with unreasonably expensive things on offer to the people buying them, sitting at the cafes, or twirling on the bull set into marble.
sources.shortName: The Best Milan Photography Locations - Popular Spots

sources.snippet: Just a few steps from the Duomo, you‚Äôll find the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, a 19th-century shopping arcade with a glass ceiling that exudes elegance and sophistication. Its stunning architecture, complete with a dome, mosaics, and luxury boutiques, makes it the perfect backdrop for stylish Instagram shots. The hustle and energy of this popular meeting spot add even more depth to your photos, capturing the essence of Milanese life.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

sources.snippet: Milan is a city that is renowned for its fashion, and style. If you're a fashion enthusiast, then you cannot miss visiting the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II. Located in the heart of Milan, this iconic shopping destination is a must-visit for anyone who loves to shop luxuriously. The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is not just a shopping mall, it's a masterpiece of architecture.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Instagrammable places in Milan

sources.snippet: Steps away from the Duomo is one of the oldest shopping malls in the world!. With its mosaic flooring and glass-dome ceiling, this mesmerising building is a great spot for stunning pictures, especially at sunrise or sunset. After you snap that perfect Instagram picture, stroll through the luxury boutiques for some window-shopping or enjoy an Aperol Spritz at one of the bars.
sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is the oldest shopping center in Italy and one of the most Instagrammable places in Milan. This tourist attraction is located next to the Milan cathedral, making it easy to take photos in both places in the morning. The building is beautiful from the outside, but the inside makes Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II so spectacular.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Milan Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: And how not to mention the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, the ‚Äúliving room of Milan‚Äù?. It is one of the most fascinating and sumptuous examples of a nineteenth-century shopping gallery, with its high dome and rich decorations. It is almost impossible to take an empty picture of it, but you can always turn your lens upwards to capture its timeless elegance.
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Milan: 10 Attractions Not to Be Missed

sources.snippet: Often referred to as the ‚ÄúLiving Room of Milan,‚Äù the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is an elegant shopping arcade that‚Äôs as photogenic as it is historic. Built in 1877, this grand arcade features a stunning glass dome complemented by intricate floor mosaics. The play of light through the dome perfectly creates a setting for your Instagram photos.
sources.shortName: Snap and Share: Top Instagrammable Spots in Milan, Italy

sources.snippet: Galleria Vittorio Emanuele ii is the oldest shopping gallery in Italy and one of the most iconic spots in Milan. This galleria is located adjacent to the Milan Duomo, so you can easily take photos at both spots in the morning. While the exterior is beautiful, the interior is what makes Galleria Vittorio Emanuele ii so spectacular.
sources.shortName: The 7 Best Milan Photo Spots | The Most Instagrammable Places in Milan

sources.snippet: The Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II in Milan is one of the oldest shopping malls in the world!. Fun fact: in the center of the gallery, the floor mosaic artwork pays homage to Rome, Florence, Turin, and Milan. Out of the four coats of arms depicted, Turin‚Äôs symbol of the bull gets particular attention.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Every time I go through, I am amazed by all the details and how well they manage to preserve it. Even though it is supposed to be the coolest spot for shopping, I have to admit I have never bought anything from there and probably I won‚Äôt soon. But entering the Galleria is an experience itself.
sources.shortName: Best Photo Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: Did you know that the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is one of the oldest shopping malls in the world?. The floor mosaic artwork in the center of the gallery pay homage to Rome, Florence, Turin, and Milan. Turin‚Äôs symbol of the bull gets particular attention due to a local tradition.
sources.shortName: Top 13 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: Adjacent to the cathedral, the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is a shopping arcade that's a work of art in itself. Stroll through this elegant space, admire its glass dome, and perhaps indulge in some upscale shopping. Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, Milan, Italy, Nov 2023
sources.shortName: One Day In Milan Italy - 10 Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: A stunning shopping gallery that has huge high roofs, high end boutiques and the most perfect lighting to grab that stunning Milan Instagram snaps. You‚Äôll find them here. View this post on Instagram
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Milan

sources.snippet: Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II is not only great for taking pics for your Instagram but also is the place to shop for designer bags and clothing.
sources.shortName: Best of Milan Photo Spots

places.name: Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II

reviews.text:
Walking into the Galleria felt like entering a dream carved in glass and light. The high dome above, the mosaic beneath my feet everything shimmered with a quiet kind of grandeur. It wasn't just a shopping arcade; it was a sacred space dressed as elegance.

There was history in the air not dusty, but alive. As if the walls had witnessed centuries of desire, beauty, longing, and grace. I didn't feel like a tourist. I felt like I had entered a story I somehow already knew.

I stood beneath the glass ceiling, watching sunlight pour in like divine gold, and felt the same sense of reverence I'd feel in a cathedral. There was luxury, yes but also soul. A reminder that beauty, when done with intention, becomes timeless.

Galleria Vittorio didn't ask me to buy anything. It asked me to remember who I am: a woman who belongs in places made of light, art, and legacy.

There are some delicious restaurants inside, but from what I've observed, they can be a bit pricey; there are certainly more affordable options. It's a great place for taking photos. The architecture is stunning. It's incredibly impressive. You can also find most of the luxury brands inside.It's a must-see after the Duomo Cathedral. The women and men here are always so stylish and well-groomed, I was impressed. :)

Attractive covered shopping arcade next to the cathedral. Lots of high end shopping options, as well as both reasonable and expensive eating options. Impressive architecture all around. Well worth strolling through and stopping for food or at least gelato. Easily combined with the cathedral next door as well as the cathedral museum.

places.generalDescription: The Duomo di Milano, also known as the Milan Cathedral, is a stunning example of Gothic architecture that took over 600 years to complete. Adorned with Candoglia marble, its facade boasts 135 spires and 3,400 statues. Inside, visitors can admire the impressive stained glass depicting biblical scenes and marvel at the enormous harmonica statue and golden Madonnina statue.

sources.snippet: Though everyone, of course, has heard of the Duomo di Milano (Milan‚Äôs Cathedral). One of the largest cathedrals in the world, second only to St Peter‚Äôs Basilica in Vatican City, the Duomo is one of the most beautiful examples of Renaissance architecture to be found anywhere in Europe. Of all the hidden gems in Milan, the Duomo‚Äôs rooftop terrace is, hands down, my all-time favourite.
sources.shortName: Hidden Milan: 10+ Unusual and Secret Spots in Milan (& Map)

sources.snippet: From Piazza del Duomo, the view of the cathedral is stunning, and you can take photos of the Duomo di Milano from different perspectives. If your budget allows, stay in one of the nearby hotels with breathtaking panorama, or on a low budget, you can enjoy the view from one of the restaurants. Don‚Äôt forget this is a crowded place and the most Instagrammable place in Milan.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Milan Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: With its intricate Gothic architecture, The Duomo di Milano is definitely one of the top must-visit hotspots for any photography enthusiast. This majestic cathedral is one of the largest in the world, naturally offering numerous photogenic angles. From its stunning facade to the detailed spires that tower to the heavens, everything is worth a click?
sources.shortName: Snap and Share: Top Instagrammable Spots in Milan, Italy

sources.snippet: Standing guard over Milan for more than 600 years, the Duomo is the most known landmark in the city. Did you know that it took over six centuries to complete and it‚Äôs actually not finished!. The last details of the cathedral were officially done in 1965 but there are still some uncarved blocks that remain to be completed as statues.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Snapping a pic in front of the famous Duomo di Milano is one of the most popular Milan shots for tourists. However, if you‚Äôd like to get this photo without any people in the background, you‚Äôll have to go early in the morning. For the best lighting with the least amount of people, I‚Äôd recommend going for sunrise!
sources.shortName: The Most Photo Worthy Spots in Milan, Italy

sources.snippet: The Duomo di Milano definitely is the most known landmark in the city. To get a shot without the crowds, it‚Äôs best to arrive there very early in the morning. For this purpose, it‚Äôs better to travel during warmer months when the sun rises earlier to ensure that nobody photobombs your picture.
sources.shortName: Top 13 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: The Duomo in Milan is a must-see for anyone visiting the city. As the most recognizable icon of Milan, this impressive Gothic cathedral captivates with its intricate pink marble facade adorned with numerous sculptures, spires, and gargoyles. It‚Äôs a true paradise for photographers.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

sources.snippet: Of course our list of the 10 most Instagrammable spots in Milan would include the Duomo di Milano. Milan‚Äôs cathedral is easily city‚Äôs the most recognisable landmark. The intricate lattice work, stone statues, and stained glass windows make for an architectural masterpiece.
sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: In the very middle of the city you‚Äôll find the ultimate Milan Instagram spot. The backdrop is as stunning and jaw dropping in terms of architecture as you‚Äôll see in any world city. You‚Äôll find more info here.
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Milan

sources.snippet: A no-brainer, the first stop has to be the Duomo di Milano, in the heart of Milan!. It's absolutely breathtaking!. The intricate facade with numerous spires and statues represents the city's rich history.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Instagrammable places in Milan
Best of Milan Photo Spots

places.name: Duomo di Milano

reviews.text:
Stepping up to the Duomo di Milano was an incredible experience, and it holds a special place in my heart because it was the very first place I ever visited as a solo traveller.

You see pictures of it, but they really don't do it justice. The sheer scale and intricate detail of the Gothic architecture are absolutely breathtaking. I remember just standing in the piazza for a good long while, just taking it all in-the spires, the statues, every little carving. It was an awe-inspiring moment that made me feel so small and, at the same time, so empowered to be out there on my own.

The best part, without a doubt, was climbing to the rooftop terraces. The views are out of this world! You get to walk right among the spires and statues, with a 360-degree panorama of Milan. I went just as the sun was starting to set, and watching the city turn to gold from up there was something I'll never forget. It was the perfect ending to my first day of solo travel, a moment of pure freedom and beauty.

Even the inside is stunning, with all the stained-glass windows and massive columns. But for me, it was that moment on the roof, surrounded by that incredible craftsmanship, that made it a truly unforgettable experience.

Duomo di Milano is a stunning example of Gothic architecture, renowned for its intricate fa√ßade and towering spires. The cathedral took nearly six centuries to complete, showcasing a blend of artistic styles that reflect the evolution of Milan itself. Visitors are often captivated by the breathtaking views from its rooftop, where they can admire the city skyline and the surrounding Alps. Inside, the vast nave and beautifully crafted stained glass windows create an atmosphere of reverence and awe, drawing in thousands of tourists and locals alike each year.

We purchased the last tickets of the day: 5:30pm. It was the perfect time as the sun was starting to set and the lighting was stunning. We choose to climb to the top by stairs which cost 16E/person. You need to book your tickets online. I recommend doing this if you're visiting Milan. Nice view from the top and the cathedral is impressive. Takes about 5min to get to the top.

places.address: P.za del Duomo, 20122 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Parco Sempione is a must-visit location in Milan, known for its beautiful landscaping by Emilio Alemagna. This park offers a perfect blend of outdoor activities such as walking trails, running paths, and dog-friendly areas. It also features historic architecture like the triumphal Arco della Pace and the romantic Ponte delle Sirenette with statues of little mermaids.

sources.snippet: Parco Sempione in Milan is a sprawling green oasis nestled near the city center, offering a serene escape with its lush lawns, picturesque lakes, and shaded pathways, providing both locals and tourists a tranquil retreat in the midst of urban hustle. Framed by the historic Castello Sforzesco, this park not only provides a peaceful respite but also serves as a cultural haven, hosting art installations and events that enhance its charm and allure.
sources.shortName: One Day In Milan Italy - 10 Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: Though not much of a ‚Äòmust-see‚Äô hidden gem as some of the other places in Milan listed here, one of the best spots in the city to head out together with friends for a picnic is that of Parco Sempione. Situated to the Northwest of Milano, a visit to the green space can easily be combined with a trip inside the Sforza Castle.
sources.shortName: Hidden Milan: 10+ Unusual and Secret Spots in Milan (& Map)

sources.snippet: The English-style landscape of Parco Sempione is a good place to rest your eyes after they've overdosed on stone and architecture, and to wander the curving pathways. Walkers, joggers, local office workers with their lunches, and parents with children in tow all enjoy the park. In the summer, concerts are held here.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

sources.snippet: If you need a break from the city's craziness, head over to Parco Sempione!. It's a massive park that's perfect for unwinding and recharging. You'll love the lush lawns, lake, and stunning views of the Arco della Pace.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Instagrammable places in Milan

places.name: Parco Sempione

reviews.text:
Parco Sempione is hands down one of my favorite parks-maybe anywhere. It's massive, but somehow still feels peaceful. There are cafes and restaurants tucked inside, wide open lawns that are actually clean and perfect for picnics, and tons of dog parks. One even has an agility course.

The views here are unreal-on one end you've got the towering Arco della Pace, and on the other, the stunning Castello Sforzesco. One of the hidden gems is the Mermaid Bridge-an old stone bridge with beautiful carvings of mermaids, built in the 1800s.

The park also has beautiful ponds and little streams, full of fish, ducks, and even turtles. It's amazing for birdwatching-tons of species, and if you look carefully, you might even spot the bright green parrots.

There's also a cool children's amusement park, basketball court, sports arena, outdoor workout stations, and tons of fountains in case you or your pup get thirsty. You'll almost always catch someone playing live music, which just adds to the magic of the park. And if you're into culture, the Triennale design museum and the Civic Aquarium are both right here too.

It truly has everything and should not be missed.

As you stroll through, you eventually reach the other side where the Arch of Triumph awaits. It's quite a walk, so make sure to bring water especially on hot days!

The park is spotlessly clean, with beautiful green spaces, ponds with ducks, a small bridge, and even outdoor gym equipment. It's an absolutely lovely place for a refreshing and enjoyable walk.

Highly recommended for a peaceful getaway in nature üå≥üåøüå±
After visiting the gardens & the palace at Versailles these hold no match. But since one is in Milan good for a walk. The best thing was live music being played here & one can sit & watch.

places.generalDescription: When visiting Parco Sempione in Milan, be sure to explore the Arco della Pace, a neoclassical triumphal arch commissioned by Napoleon to commemorate his victories. This majestic structure is made of marble from the Swiss Alps and stands as the starting point of the road connecting Milan and Paris. Adorned with Corinthian columns and intricate reliefs depicting historical moments, it symbolizes peace and prosperity.

sources.snippet: View this post on InstagramA post shared by Irene Ibarra (@_baire). When construction of the ‚ÄúArch of Peace‚Äù began in 1807 to celebrate Napoleon being crowned as King of Italy, it was meant to be an Arch of Triumph. But after Napoleon‚Äôs defeat, the project was abandoned temporarily and not completed until 1838.
sources.shortName: 9 Instagrammable Places in Milan for Perfect Pictures

sources.snippet: Arco della Pace is a neoclassical triumphal arch of majestic proportions, gracing the entrance to Parco Sempione and exuding timeless elegance with its Corinthian columns, intricate reliefs, and a commanding presence that symbolizes peace and prosperity. From a quick glance from far away, it reminds you of Arc de Triomphe in Paris. While both are monumental triumphal arches, Arco della Pace in Milan is a lot smaller, about half the size of Arc de Triomphe.
sources.shortName: One Day In Milan Italy - 10 Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs free to visit, so don‚Äôt miss out on one of the most Instagrammable places in Milan. Which also offers fascinating photo opportunities for both solo and couples photographers. The best light is at sunrise or sunset, but you can also visit during the day as it‚Äôs not crowded like the Duomo di Milano or the Galleria Vittori Emanuel II. After visiting, you can relax in the nearby park and take pictures from different perspectives.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Milan Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: If you're ever in Milan, you should definitely check out Arco della Pace in the Sempione district. It was first built to celebrate Napoleon's victories, but now it represents peace and calmness in the city. The arch is made of fancy carved marble columns with beautiful sculptures, which makes it a great place for taking romantic photos.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Instagrammable places in Milan

sources.snippet: The  Arco della Pace(‚ÄúArch of Peace‚Äù) is another well-known landmark in Milan. Although it was constructed in the 1800s, the concept of a gate in the  Porta Sempione area of the city dates back to the Roman Walls of Milan. Interestingly enough, this particular arch commemorates Napoleon‚Äôs brief presence in Italy.
sources.shortName: The Most Photo Worthy Spots in Milan, Italy

sources.snippet: Arco della Pace features detailed beautiful architecture, similar to the Duomo di Milan, but typically with less crowds. This ‚ÄúArch of Peace‚Äù is located right by the north entrance to Parco Sempione, the biggest park in Milan. Standing at 25 meters tall, the arc will make a striking backdrop to any picture.
sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: Arches in the Roman style have been built in many cities around the world. This one, called the Arch of Peace (Arco della Pace), was built in 1807 under the Napoleonic rule. This gate marked the place where the new Strada del Sempione entered Milan.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: The Arco della Pace is another of the most popular locations for photographers in Milan. This solemn triumphal arch at the beginning of Corso Sempione gives its best at dawn, sunset and after a rainy day: try to capture its reflection in a puddle.
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Milan: 10 Attractions Not to Be Missed

sources.snippet: Arco della Pace, the Arch of Peace, is another great photo spot in Milan. This arch was built in 1807 and served as a gateway to Milan. The details of the Arco della Pace are remarkable and create a wonderful backdrop for a photo.
sources.shortName: The 7 Best Milan Photo Spots | The Most Instagrammable Places in Milan

sources.snippet: At the opposite end of Parco Sempione is the Arco della Pace or Arch of Peace, like a mini Arch d‚ÄôTriomphe. Fun fact: it was built on the direct road from Paris to herald Napoleon‚Äôs triumphant return to Italy.
sources.shortName: 23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

sources.snippet: Arco della Pace ‚Äì Very central, close to all the attractions of Milan, but also a very green area as its next to Parco Sempione. Perfect for families who want quiet, but also a central position.
sources.shortName: BEST Areas & Hotels According To A Local

sources.snippet: After that, we just strolled around, relaxed at a park, took some pictures at the Arco della Pace and enjoyed our day. Long gone are the feeling of frustration...
sources.shortName: Best of Milan Photo Spots

sources.snippet: This gate marked the place where the new Strada del Sempione entered Milan. This road is still in use today and connects Milan to Paris.
sources.shortName: Top 13 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

places.name: Arco della Pace

reviews.text:
The Arco della Pace, or Arch of Peace, is a grand neoclassical monument in Milan. Its construction began in 1807 under Napoleon to celebrate his victories, but it was finished in 1838 by the Austrians. The arch was ultimately dedicated to the peace established after the Napoleonic Wars.
Adorned with intricate reliefs and sculptures, it features a striking bronze chariot on top. Located at the end of a historic road, it beautifully links Parco Sempione with the city's lively center. This monument is a symbol of both a military past and a hopeful future.

Nice arch monument built during Napoleon's time. Looked nice. Some event was going on nearby and the place right next to it was all getting ready for that. We found just a few tourists here. Good place for few clicks. Visit if you have time.

An elegant monument in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Arco della Pace is a majestic triumphal arch that offers a quieter and more peaceful experience compared to other tourist spots in Milan. The surrounding park is perfect for a calm walk or relaxing with a view of this impressive neoclassical structure. It's especially beautiful at sunset, when the light hits the arch just right. A great place to slow down, take photos, and enjoy the atmosphere.

places.generalDescription: Located in a stunning palazzo that once served as a Jesuit college and observatory, the Pinacoteca di Brera is a must-visit for art enthusiasts. This museum boasts an impressive collection of Italian paintings, with works by renowned artists such as Raphael, Tintoretto, and Mantegna. The palazzo's rich history adds to the allure of this cultural gem in Milan.

sources.snippet: The Renaissance Palazzo di Brera, built between 1651 and 1773, was originally a Jesuit college, but since 1776 has been the Accademia di Belle Arti (Academy of Fine Arts). Along with a library and observatory, it contains the Pinacoteca di Brera, one of Italy's finest art museums. Much of the art was acquired as churches closed or were demolished, and the museum is especially strong in paintings by northern Italian masters.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

sources.snippet: The Pinacoteca Brera is home to one of the most important collections of Italian paintings. In the museum, you‚Äôll find works by masters such as Raphael, Caravaggio, and Bellini, offering perfect opportunities for art-inspired photography. Don‚Äôt forget to capture the beautiful courtyard of the museum, a popular spot for artistic shots.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

sources.snippet: It houses the prestigious Brera Academy of Fine Arts and the Pinacoteca di Brera, an important art gallery. The presence of art and creativity in the district adds an artistic flair to the surroundings. Photographers can find inspiration in the artistic atmosphere and capture the essence of creativity in their images.
sources.shortName: Brera District & Other Top Photo Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: The Pinacoteca di Brera is one of the most important art museums in Italy. It has nearly 40 halls of works from the Renaissance and Baroque periods. Explore the art and photograph the courtyard (closed on Mondays).
sources.shortName: 23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

sources.snippet: Museums in Milan showcase the city and country‚Äôs history and art. They are also incredibly photogenic!. Two of my favorites are the Pinacoteca di Brera and Pinacoteca Ambrosiana.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

places.name: Pinacoteca di Brera

reviews.text: The museum is absolutely gorgeous. There are many historical paintings from famous authors inside. Although I am not really interested in art I definitely would recommend including it in your Milan's trip itinerary

The museum is well ventilated with AC. There are lots of paintings of Jesus Christ and Mary. Took me about 1.5-2 hours to see everything. What I liked the most were the sculptures and statues. Perfect place to go if you love early Renaissance art. The staff speaks English which is good and for each painting, there is a description in English. The price is 15‚Ç¨ which is a bit much.

Beautiful art gallery that contains several works and most of them by Italian artists. Some of these are famous for more while others only for those who have a particular interest. The rooms should be better organised but 90 minutes will pass quickly also thanks to the audio guide. Fortunately I didn't have to book but I noticed that after 12 pm, the turnout was greatly increased.

places.generalDescription: Sforzesco Castle, one of the largest castles in Europe, is a magnificent medieval-Renaissance fortress that stands as a historic symbol of Milan. Built between the 14th and 15th centuries for defensive purposes, it now houses various museums showcasing significant artworks by renowned artists such as da Vinci and Michelangelo.

sources.snippet: Formerly one of the largest citadels in Europe, and once home to Leonardo da Vinci, Sforzesco Castle now makes a great spot to relax and snap some Insta-worthy photos. While you‚Äôll find loads of great spots throughout the castle grounds, there are certainly a few hot spots!. Make sure you stop at the majestic fountain in front of the castle.
sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: Sforzesco Castle is one of the more unique photo spots in Milan. This is one of the top attractions in Milan, yet is often overlooked when it comes to Instagrammable spots. To get a great photo at Sforzesco Castle, you will want to go to the fountain in front of the castle.
sources.shortName: The 7 Best Milan Photo Spots | The Most Instagrammable Places in Milan

sources.snippet: Many places around the impressive Sforzesco castle are among the most Instagrammable places in Milan ‚Äì take your pick!. The ramparts, the tower, the fascinating artwork, the secret underground paths and tunnels (Strada Coperta della Ghirlanda), the frescoed courtyard‚Ä¶
sources.shortName: 23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

places.name: Sforzesco Castle

reviews.text:
Very beautiful castle with lots of exhibitions on different topics. We spent hours there. At the end it was too much input.
Every first and third Tuesday of the month the entrance is free. Not sure if the whole day or after 2pm (read different information). We arrived at 2:30pm and it was definitely free. Closing time was 5:30pm.

Historic castle belonging to the royal family of Milan.  We enjoyed the massive size of the castle, had learned a lot during our guided tour of Milan, which took us through the castle.

I believe there's a lot to see here, but our guided tour took us through rather quickly explaining everything we needed to know about the historic castle.

Tremendous castle museum, well worth spending a morning or afternoon here. Packed full with art of every kind, from paintings to sculpture to furniture and other material culture items. Buildings themselves also of interest. Lockers in the basement to store bags, which are not allowed in the paid areas. Very good value. Could make more money by charging more and having a bigger gift shop.

places.generalDescription: Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio is a Romanesque church in Milan, Italy, known for its elegant courtyard and the crypt where the remains of St. Ambrose are displayed. Founded by St. Ambrose in 379 CE, it is considered one of the most ancient churches in Italy and a historically significant medieval building in Lombardy.

sources.snippet: Among the most ancient churches in Milan, the Basilica of Sant‚ÄôAmbrogio was built in 387 by St. Ambrose, in an area where a lot of martyrs of the Roman persecutions had been buried. The first name of the church was Basilica Martyrum and it was later named after him. At first, the Basilica was outside Milan, but over the centuries, the city grew up around it and it‚Äôs now located in the center!
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: If you want to combine photo ops and a bit of history, then this one is for you. Dating all the way back to 379, Basilica of Sant‚ÄôAmbrogio is an enchanting photo spot in Milan. It‚Äôs among the most ancient churches in all of Italy and located in the center of the city.
sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: Among the most ancient churches in Milan, the Basilica of Sant‚ÄôAmbrogio was built in 387 by St. Ambrose. The first name of the church was Basilica Martyrum because it was built in an area where a lot of martyrs of the Roman persecution hat been buried.
sources.shortName: Top 13 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

places.name: Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio

reviews.text:
A truly breathtaking place - the Basilica of Sant'Ambrogio is a must-visit in Milan for history and architecture lovers. The atmosphere is peaceful and humbling, and the mosaics and frescoes are absolutely stunning. Every corner of this place tells a story, and you can really feel the layers of history all around you.

There was no wait to enter, and the experience was calm and unhurried, which made it even more special. Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates sacred art, Romanesque architecture, and places with deep spiritual and historical roots.

Sadly we could not see more of it. We entered and a man told us to leave, even though the basilica had fo be opened up until 12:30.. it was 12 when we came. Make sure you come earlier or much later, so you could enjoy it to the fullest.

This is one of the most popular churches in Milan (after the Duomo and Santa Maria della Grazie), and for a good reason, as it is one of the oldest and beautiful churches in the city, also consecrated to its most beloved saint. The architecture we see is mostly of 11-12th centuries (or earlier) with minimal alterations. The most beautiful part of the church is the Oratory of San Vittore in Ciel d'Oro, with amazing 5th century mosaics and small adjasent museum (requires a small fee to enter). There is also 13th century mosaic in apse (although heavily restored), intricately carved Romanesque pulpit, and many other artistic miracles inside.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Milan, the Chiesa di San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore is a stunning 16th-century church that once served as a monastery. Often referred to as the Sistine Chapel of Milan, this hidden gem boasts an array of vibrant frescoes by Bernardino Luini, a contemporary of Leonardo Da Vinci. The church features an expansive nave divided into two sections: one for the congregation and another for the nuns' choir.

sources.snippet: Often referred to as Milan‚Äôs answer to the Sistine Chapel, one wander into the stunning 16th-century frescoed interior of the San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore and it will quickly become clear how the church gained its nickname. Once attached to an important female convent of the Benedictine Order, the former monastery has since been transformed into an archaeological museum. The church itself remains free to visit and services are held every Sunday.
sources.shortName: Hidden Milan: 10+ Unusual and Secret Spots in Milan (& Map)

places.name: Chiesa di San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore

reviews.text:
Located at Corso Magenta, 15, 20123 Milan MI, Italy üáÆüáπ.
This chapel is quite underrated because it doesn't look as eye catching as the famous Milano Duomo. Once I walked inside though, I was struck by the sheer beauty of it. Everything in San Maurizio has colour, whether it's paintings, mosaics or gold glitters everywhere. Nothing is uncovered by some form of colour including the pillars, ceilings and walls. The church is nicknamed the ‚ÄòSistine Chapel' of Milan.
The church is located at what used to be the most important convent for women in Milan. The construction of this church took about fifteen years and took place in the sixteenth century. The building was split into two parts ‚Äì one for the nuns and one for the faithful ‚Äì and it was not until the end of the eighteenth century that this strict barrier disappeared.
The church is not very big, but it's definitely worth visiting. There's no admission fee and the staff are friendly and welcoming. I am so glad I visited San Maurizio. Thumbs up!!! üëçüëçüëç

Absolutely must see. Hidden away gem.
One of only two churches in Milan where every corner in the monastery is covered in stunning hand paintings. Some great history behind the cut icons from when the church was used as a shelter for Napoleon army during the war. Must visit and spend some time to appreciate the stunning paintings.

A local artisan, jeweler, sent us hear. Breathtaking views
Oils
Portraits.

Various artists from the 1500
Bringing the words of the Bible to life.                 The experience was solem and reflective.

Worth the walk.
Be blessed:
Not by idols
Not by tradition
Not by a religion
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
But
live for and Follow the Lord Jesus Christ

places.generalDescription: Teatro alla Scala, also known as La Scala, is an opulent 18th-century theater renowned for its Italian opera and ballet performances. The theater features a museum showcasing its rich history through exhibitions of costumes, musical instruments, photographs, and set designs. Additionally, the Livia Simoni Library houses an extensive collection of 150,000 volumes of librettos, scores, and periodicals.

sources.snippet: For another place that is gorgeous both inside and out but far less controversial, Milan has the Teatro alla Scala: a staggering tour de force, as any place with so much artful, glorious history ought to be. Wait for a show to start or end to get a picture of the fancy opera-going folk walking those famous steps or come late at night to take a photograph of the building from across the piazza, silent, still, and dignified. If you really want to go all out, you can move inside and get a few detail shots.
sources.shortName: The Best Milan Photography Locations - Popular Spots

sources.snippet: Considered the most prestigious opera house in the world, Teatro alla Scala has rung with the music of all the great operatic composers and singers, and its audiences - the theater seats 2,800 people - are known (and feared) as the most demanding in Italy. The season begins in early December and runs through May, but tickets are often difficult to come by. The best way of getting tickets is through your hotel concierge, but it's worth checking at the box office.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

sources.snippet: Built over 240 years ago, many great artists have performed at Teatro alla Scala, including Verdi, Toscanini, Maria Callas, and Luciano Pavarotti.
sources.shortName: 23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

places.name: Teatro alla Scala

reviews.text: The museum has many performing art relevant collections.  The theater offers beautiful forms of architecture.  I definitely will schedule to see show here next time I'm in Milan.

Went on self guided tour. It featured several rooms with portraits of composers and performers through history and a lovely exhibit on ballet. It was very short, and it did not focus as much on the music as the art of movement, but it is worth seeing the theater.

A must-visit when in Milan, but plan ahead. We went during the August shut-down, so there wasn't much to see apart from the tour. Still, the tour was interesting and included a visit to the theatre boxes, plus entry to the attached museum. Definitely book tours in advance, and if you can, time your visit outside of August so you get the full experience of seeing an opera.

places.generalDescription: Santa Maria delle Grazie is a stunning Renaissance church located in the historic center of Milan. It features an elaborate Gothic interior and is renowned for being the home of Leonardo da Vinci's masterpiece, The Last Supper. This UNESCO World Heritage site attracts visitors from all over the world who come to admire this exceptional artwork. The church itself is a magnificent combination of Gothic and Renaissance architecture, making it a must-see attraction in Milan.

sources.snippet: Santa Maria delle Grazie houses Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs Last Supper (entry only with a ticket ‚Äì make sure you prebook). Of course, the masterpiece is one of the most Instagrammable places in Milan, but don‚Äôt neglect other spots around the church. Try the view of the church from the cloisters, for example.
sources.shortName: 23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

sources.snippet: The Santa Maria delle Grazie, is best known for Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs famous fresco, The Last Supper‚Äù. However, the church itself offers many other photographic opportunities. Its beautiful architecture and charming courtyard create an atmosphere that translates perfectly into stunning shots.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

sources.snippet: Santa Maria delle Grazie is a UNESCO World Heritage church and Dominican convent. The most notable thing about this church is that the fresco of Leonardo da Vinci depicting the Last Supper is preserved in its refectory!. Location: Piazza di Santa Maria delle Grazie, 20123 Milano
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: If you love art, you should definitely visit Santa Maria delle Grazie. The church looks beautiful from the outside, but the inside is even more amazing. There's a room called the refectory where you can see the famous painting, The Last Supper, by Leonardo da Vinci.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Instagrammable places in Milan

sources.snippet: Santa Maria delle Grazie is an UNESCO World Heritage church. The most notable thing about this church is that the fresco of Leonardo da Vinci depicting the Last Supper is preserved in its refectory!
sources.shortName: Top 13 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

places.name: Basilica di Santa Maria delle Grazie

reviews.text: Very beautiful place! It's best to go right when it opens. It's free and very cool to actually see the last supper painting in person. Don't expect anything HUGE, it's not too big but it is amazing to see in person. It has a nice courtyard and beautiful other paintings. The gift shop is has nice things to buy to save the memory. The workers/volunteers are very nice. I still don't get why holy water costs money, blessings should be free right?

Book tickets well in advance - they sell out quickly. We ended up booking a combined Last Supper and Milan city tour, and it was a great choice. Having an expert guide gave us valuable commentary on the art, and the city tour added a local's perspective that was both informative and engaging. If you can, plan the city tour for your first day in Milan - it's a perfect introduction to the key sights and sounds of the city. Be ready to walk, so bring comfortable shoes. An unforgettable experience. The Last Supper itself was beautiful, though it was unexpectedly dimmer in real life. But nonetheless it was a moving experience.

I love this beautiful church! It is famous for the Last Supper's exhibit but the church itself with the little garden in the middle of the court yard is so peaceful and spiritual. I love the Church's shop too. This church has a great vibe about it. The church is always open and free  But the exhibit required tickets well in advance!

places.address: Via Giuseppe Antonio Sassi, 3, 20123 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Chiesa di Santa Maria presso San Satiro is an elegant church dating back to the 15th century, located near the Duomo in Milan. It was founded by Archbishop Ansperto in the 9th century and is dedicated to Saint Satyrus.

sources.snippet: From the outside, this church on a shopping street not far from Piazza del Duomo seems relatively small and unimpressive. Step inside to see that it is quite grand, its majestic, deep, vaulted sanctuary stretching into an apse that's nearly the length of the main part of the church.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

places.name: Chiesa di Santa Maria

reviews.text: Maybe a hidden gem in Milano. Not very people know this place. The depth you see in de church is an optical illusion. If you stand on the side of the wall you'll see there is no depth. Beautiful and mindblowing constructure.

Very small church not mentioned in common guides but worth seeing. I get there only because random lady helped me with the map and told me about it. And I don' t regret it. The illussion of 3d is great! The photos of it fooled everyone! In addition it is very quiet church when You can rest and pray in a silence.. away from Milano noice which is right behind the door.

A really beautiful church. Tucked away in the centre of Milan- it is easily missed. The interior was stunning! The use of Trompe-l'≈ìil really gave depth to this amazing building. It was built in the 1400s. The church's trompe-l'≈ìil was one of the earliest examples of the style in history.

places.generalDescription: Bosco Verticale, also known as the Vertical Forest, is a pioneering architectural project in Milan. Comprising two towers adorned with trees, shrubs, and plants on every floor, it serves as a sustainable model for urban living. Designed by Stefano Boeri Studio, this innovative structure houses around 900 trees and over 20,000 plants that contribute to noise reduction, oxygen production, and solar radiation protection.

sources.snippet: Also known as the ‚ÄúVertical Forest,‚Äù these two residential towers in the Porta Nuova district are covered in more than 15,000 plants, 800 trees and 4,500 shrubs. The towers were designed by architect Stefano Boeri to help keep temperatures consistent in the buildings no matter the season, as well as to protect against noise and to provide a space for birds and insects to live. Of course, not only is all this vegetation good for the environment, but it also looks incredibly cool in an Instagram snap.
sources.shortName: 9 Instagrammable Places in Milan for Perfect Pictures

sources.snippet: Bosco Verticale a.k.a. The Vertical Forest is a pair of residential towers that showcase Milan‚Äôs commitment to sustainable architecture. These stunning skyscrapers host over 900 trees and 20,000 plants, creating a vertical forest that likewise helps reduce the city‚Äôs smog while producing oxygen. With Its nature-centric and innovative design, Bosco Verticale has won the International Highrise Award in 2014 and was recognized as one of the 5 0 Most Iconic Skyscrapers in 2019.
sources.shortName: Snap and Share: Top Instagrammable Spots in Milan, Italy

sources.snippet: Located nearby, the Bosco Verticale (below left) is a pair of residential towers known for their innovative design featuring a significant amount of greenery, contributing to the sustainability and aesthetics of the area. There are many other skyscrapers, stylish buildings and new developments (above right) around Piazza Gae Aulenti. It was within minutes walk from our accommodation.
sources.shortName: One Day In Milan Italy - 10 Best Photo Spots

sources.snippet: Bosco Verticale, or the ‚ÄúVertical Forest,‚Äù is a pair of innovative skyscrapers that have become an icon of modern Milanese architecture. Designed by Stefano Boeri, these towers are covered with over 20,000 trees and shrubs, creating an extraordinary green facade that changes with the seasons. The blend of nature and urban design makes for unique and visually captivating photos.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

sources.snippet: Milan is famous for its historic landmarks, but the Bosco Verticale is something else!. These amazing residential towers, designed by architect Stefano Boeri, are covered in greenery from top to bottom, making them stand out against the city skyline. It is home to over 900 trees and thousands of other plants, which cover the building from top to bottom.
sources.shortName: Top 8 Instagrammable places in Milan

sources.snippet: Recognised as one of the most beautiful and innovative high rises in the world, Bosco Verticale is a must see!. And if you consider yourself a modern architecture fan, you really won‚Äôt want to miss this. Also known as the vertical forest, this architectural complex makes for some super unique photo opportunities.
sources.siteName: Europe Famous Hostels | Good times, great memories
sources.shortName: Top 10 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: If you are interested in modern architecture, you must visit Bosco Verticale, because a truly unique place. Since the creation of Bosco Verticale, many other vertical forests have been built around the world. The Bosco Verticale is a beautiful photo location that has become famous on the Internet.
sources.shortName: 7 Best Milan Instagram Spots

sources.snippet: Bosco Verticale (Vertical Forest) is an architectural complex consisting of a pair of residential towers conceived with the help of botanists. It is a great example of urban eco-design and a really unique place!. If you are interested in modern architecture, visiting Bosco Verticale is a must!
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

sources.snippet: Bosco Verticale ( Vertical Forest) is an architectural complex nearby Piazza Gae Aulenti and a great example of urban ecodesign.
sources.shortName: Top 13 Most Instagrammable Spots in Milan
23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

places.name: Bosco Verticale

reviews.text:
Bosco Verticale in Milan stands as a potent symbol of futuristic architecture, boldly charting a course for urban development that harmonizes the built environment with the vitality of nature. Its very conception, twin towers draped in a living skin of thousands of trees and plants, transcends conventional notions of residential buildings. This pioneering integration of raw, untamed nature directly onto a highly refined architectural structure is a hallmark of its forward-thinking design.

The project envisions a future where cities are not sterile concrete jungles but thriving ecosystems, enhancing biodiversity and mitigating the environmental impact of dense urban living. The sophisticated engineering required to sustain such a complex vertical forest ‚Äì from irrigation and structural support to plant selection and maintenance ‚Äì showcases an advanced approach to building design.

Furthermore, Bosco Verticale anticipates a growing awareness of ecological responsibility in urban planning. It suggests a future where buildings actively contribute to air purification, carbon sequestration, and the creation of microclimates, moving beyond mere shelter to become active participants in the urban environment.

The aesthetic impact is also profoundly futuristic. The dynamic interplay of the stark architectural lines with the organic, ever-changing foliage creates a visually striking and constantly evolving facade. This blurs the traditional boundaries between the artificial and the natural, hinting at a future where technology and ecology are seamlessly interwoven.

Beyond the immediate visual and environmental benefits, Bosco Verticale serves as a powerful prototype, inspiring architects and urban planners worldwide to reimagine the potential of vertical greening. It posits a future where such integrated natural-architectural solutions become commonplace, transforming our cities into more sustainable, resilient, and aesthetically rich living spaces. The innovative spirit and ecological foresight embodied by Bosco Verticale firmly position it as a cornerstone of future architectural thought and practice.

The vertical garden is right next to some other tall Milan buildings and a really nice park
It was nice to see the vertical garden but the one on the ground was lovely.
There is a great pool which overflows on the side with lots of fish insects and some birds floating there with their fledgings.
There is an open air gym as well as a playground... And even some static recliners to lay back in and just soak up the sun.
Best of all it's free so enjoy it :)

These residential towers are covered with thousands of trees and plants.
Stunning example of sustainable architecture. It's an inspiring blend of modern urban living

places.address: Via Gaetano de Castillia, 11, 20124 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: The Leonardo da Vinci Museum of Science and Technology, located in Milan, is a significant institution in Italy and one of the most visited museums in Lombardy. It spans an area of 50,000 square meters and comprises various pavilions with historical significance. Housed within a former 16th-century Olivetan monastery, the museum showcases over thirty models of Leonardo da Vinci's innovative inventions, including submarines and aircraft.

sources.snippet: Housed in a former Olivetan monastery, the Leonardo da Vinci National Museum of Science and Technology illustrates the history of science and technology from the work of early scientists into modern times. Of particular interest is the Leonardo da Vinci Gallery with working models of many of his inventions and machinery, created from da Vinci's drawings. In the physics exhibits are apparatus used by Galileo, Newton, and Volta, and there are sections relating to optics, acoustics, telegraphy, transport, shipping, railroads, flying, metallurgy, motor vehicles, timekeeping, and timber.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

places.name: Leonardo da Vinci Museum of Science and Technology

reviews.text:
Amazing space definitely worth the visit even you don't care about science. It's a huge and beautiful place in itself.

The museum themes range from space to history to war fair and are nicely organized.  Plan your visit wisely because it's a big place that can take a good portion of your afternoon.

Architecture enthusiasts will have the same thrillingly wonderful experience as I had seeing original versions of the books we still get to read at university and all of the beautiful models exposed.

100% children approved, made me wish I was a child again to be even more mesmerized by the amazing working prototypes build after Da Vince's drawings and play at the interactive attractions.

They have amazing folders you can bring home, for children and adults, in many languages and substancial amount of interesting information.

The souvenir shop is affordable compared to otter museums around and has great products.

This is amazing value for money at ‚Ç¨10 per adult, it could be ‚Ç¨25 per adult and still be good value.  You can easily spend 2 hours or more here.  The first building contains a lot of historical pieces from steel forging to the early digital age.  There are 3 beautiful classic cars also.  Then the second building contains a broad collection of ships and airplanes.  This includes a full sized sailing ship across 3 floors.   The third building was a locomotive shed (you shouldn't call them  "trains" I believe). It has a collection of around 15 locomotives and trams.  Finally there is a full sized submarine outside. It looks like a U-boat but maybe an Italian version?  It's number didn't start with "U".   Kids, especially boys would love here.

We didn't buy tickets in advance, just showed up at the building and got in immediately with no line. This was on a Thursday at around 11am.

This is a must visit whether you are an adult or a with young children. Fascinating place and impressive what Leonardo was able to achieve in 1 lifetime. Extensive place, so technically you could spend the whole day here, but you can select 2 or 3 areas to cover things like airplanes, automobiles, architecture, etc

places.address: Via San Vittore, 21, 20123 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: The Poldi Pezzoli Museum, also known as Museo Poldi Pezzoli, is a charming house museum that boasts an extensive array of Renaissance Italian paintings and a remarkable collection of decorative arts. The museum features an impressive assortment of items such as glasses, clocks, porcelain, jewelry, armor, and tapestries.

sources.snippet: An elegant old patrician house is the setting for this art museum, which originated in the 19th century as the private collection of Gian Giacomo Poldi Pezzoli and his mother, Rosa Trivulzio. Highlights are paintings by Botticelli, Mantegna, Piero della Francesca, Guard√≠, and other artists, as well as jewelry, silver, bronzes, porcelains, Etruscan pottery, armor, and weapons. Textiles in the museum include Flemish and Persian carpets, tapestries, a large collection of hand-worked lace, and a very rare embroidery designed by Botticelli.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

places.name: Poldi Pezzoli Museum

reviews.text:
one of the best museum homes in Milano.
a must visit for medieval art lovers, though the eye is without doubt captured by the whimsical fountain by the spiral staircase: highly suggest enjoying it by all angles, whilst being soothed by the running water.

Poldi Pezzoli was one of the highlights of our trip to Milan. The collection is stunning and beautifully displayed in a historic home, but what really made the difference was the staff. We visited five museums in Milan, and this was the only one where the staff were genuinely friendly, welcoming, and helpful üòáüôèüèªüíû
Since we had a baby in a walker who was sometimes noisy and restless, we were worried about the visit, but the staff were kind, patient, and understanding throughout. Their warmth made us feel comfortable and turned a great visit into a truly memorable one. Thanks to their professional and friendly staff üíöHighly recommended!
Interesting museum and I really liked the lighting ‚Äì it was dark but the paintings were well-lit

places.address: Via Alessandro Manzoni, 12, 20121 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Milan, the Santuario di San Bernardino alle Ossa is a captivating 13th-century Catholic church that offers a unique glimpse into history and artistry. This remarkable site features an ossuary adorned with intricate frescoes, where thousands of human skulls and bones create a haunting yet fascinating atmosphere. The chapel evokes comparisons to Paris's Cemetery of the Innocents, as it houses remains unearthed after a bell tower collapse in 1964.

sources.snippet: Or St. Bernard of the Bones in English, this sanctuary delivers on the promise given in its name. Visit the chapel of this church and see the bones and skulls of those deceased who had no space reserved for them in the cemetery adjacent and had to be put to rest here, for all to see. Yes, the sight is macabre and taking pictures may be uncouth, but the images you will take from the experience may just be worth the risk of a ghost haunting you for the rest of all eternity.
sources.shortName: The Best Milan Photography Locations - Popular Spots

sources.snippet: Nestled in the shadows of the Duomo di Milano, the San Bernadino alle Ossa is the kind of chapel you definitely wouldn‚Äôt expect to find in a busy modern city. For, the interior walls are decorated with countless human skulls and bones, reportedly the victims of the plague. The story goes that in the 13th-century, an adjacent cemetery ran out of space and so a chapel was constructed to hold bones.
sources.shortName: Hidden Milan: 10+ Unusual and Secret Spots in Milan (& Map)

places.name: Santuario di San Bernardino alle Ossa

reviews.text:
You should visit here to see the skull collection in the church. We find it quite interesting why a church has such a collection. Is it to scare or make people to think of their precious time in the world or remind them of the death or the Creator?

It is free and everyone should visit this place to question and observe.

As with every church I stumbled on in Milan, the inside was absolutely breathtaking. So many intricate details and beautiful art adorning the walls and ceiling. A nice, lighter breath of fresh air compared to the other sanctuary room a few steps away‚Ä¶

But you cannot miss the other room! It's macabre and fascinating all at once. The sheer number of bones on the walls was enough to make me shudder. A fascinating experience.

Impressive place, interesting for the Catholic iconography and attractive architecture. Always interesting to see the difference between Catholic churches and Protestant places. Domed roof rather attractive. Free to enter and look around. Quiet inside. Good place to sit. Steady stream of tourists but not too busy generally.

places.address: Piazza Santo Stefano, 20122 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Pirelli HangarBicocca is a contemporary art museum located in a former locomotive manufacturing plant, now transformed into a center for cultural projects. Situated in the artsy Bicocca district, it features changing temporary exhibitions alongside the dramatic permanent installation called The Seven Heavenly Palaces by German artist Anselm Kiefer.

sources.snippet: View this post on InstagramA post shared by Pirelli HangarBicocca (@pirelli_hangarbicocca). Located in a gigantic former train factory, this cavernous industrial space on the far northern reaches of Milan houses a permanent installation by artist Anselm Kiefer‚Äî The Seven Heavenly Palaces‚Äîwhere visitors can walk through seven cement towers ranging from 43- to 52-feet high, and also view five large-scale paintings by the artist. The towers look just as cool on Instagram as they do in person.
sources.shortName: 9 Instagrammable Places in Milan for Perfect Pictures

sources.snippet: In one of the most dynamic and popular of the arts neighborhoods emerging from former industrial districts, a former locomotive manufacturing plant has been converted into the Pirelli Hangar Bicocca, a center for contemporary art and cultural projects. Changing temporary exhibitions fill two of the three galleries, while the third houses the dramatic permanent installation, The Seven Heavenly Palaces. A collection of concrete towers by the German artist Anselm Kiefer towers over visitors, and accompanying the exhibition are "Bubbles" with in-depth texts, videos, audio, and interactive events relating to the exhibitions or to contemporary arts.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

sources.snippet: Pirelli HangarBicocca is a contemporary art museum located in a former Pirelli tire factory, known for its large-scale installations. The raw, industrial space provides a dramatic backdrop for the artworks, and one of the most iconic installations‚Äî‚Äù The Seven Heavenly Palaces‚Äù by Anselm Kiefer‚Äîis a monumental piece just begging to be captured in photos. Address: Via Chiese, 2
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

sources.snippet: The Pirelli Foundation has converted a gigantic former train factory into an arts space. The art installation ‚ÄúThe Seven Heavenly Palaces‚Äù by Anselm Kiefer has seven structures made of reinforced concrete and shipping containers, rising 13 to 19 metres high and weighing 90 tonnes. These towering palaces are worth a photo, or 10.
sources.shortName: 23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

places.name: Pirelli Hangar Bicocca

reviews.text:
This is an absolute must visit if you like contemporary art. The place is very big.  The exhibition of Anselm Kiefer is impressive. Huge scale artworks. Pieces that are equivalent of 6 stories high.  That immensely big the place is.
The other exhibition halls are also huge. Displaying monumental works.
The exhibitions are properly curated. And to think the entrance is completely free.
Thank to whoever funds projects like this.
Art should be accessible for everyone.
It is a very impressive art space and hospitable to artists creating installations. A must when visiting Milano

By far the best place we visited in Milan. An enormous industrial space turned into a modern art gallery that can house large scale art installations. Interesting and thought-proviking pieces were on display. The building itself is also awesome, the inner units are celeverly organised and the staff is prepared and kind. There is a really nice "bistrot" in the building, which is also worth a visit. If anybody has any connection to modern art, this place is a must-see.

places.generalDescription: When visiting Milan, one of the must-see attractions is the Duomo di Milano, a stunning gothic cathedral that has taken several centuries to complete. The cathedral's pink marble facade adorned with numerous statues, spires, and gargoyles makes it a truly spectacular sight. It is considered by many as the main reason to visit Milan. In addition to its iconic beauty, there is much more to explore in Milan beyond the famous cathedral.

sources.snippet: The massive Cathedral of Santa Maria Nascente, which the Milanese call just "Il Duomo" is among the world's largest (it holds up to 40,000 people) and most magnificent churches, the ultimate example of the Flamboyant Gothic style. It was begun in the 14th century, but its fa√ßade was not completed until the early 1800s, under Napoleon. The roof is topped by 135 delicately carved stone pinnacles and the exterior is decorated with 2,245 marble statues.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan
23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

places.name: Duomo

reviews.text: The Duomo is absolutely stunning and a must-see! The atmosphere around it is vibrant and full of life, even late at night. We visited at 10 PM, and the area was still buzzing with energy, with people enjoying the sights and the lively surroundings.

You can get off the metro right at Duomo Square, and the view as you step outside is absolutely stunning. The station itself is a bit old, but it's very convenient with solid connections to other metro lines and buses.

A beautiful gothic cathedral. Amazing attention to detail both inside and out. The trip to the roof was fantastic. The museum and ruins under the cathedral were interesting too. Well worth the combined ticket price. Just scan a QR code whilst queuing to purchase. Very straightforward.

places.address: P.za del Duomo, 20122 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Fondazione Prada is a cultural hub in Milan, housed in a unique complex of buildings designed by Rem Koolhaas. The foundation's mission is to promote contemporary art through its various spaces, including the Museum for temporary exhibitions, the Cinema for multimedia events, and a ten-story tower with a permanent exhibition space and rooftop bar. This 19,000 square meter area combines existing structures with new additions like the Podium, Cinema, and Tower.

sources.snippet: Fondazione Prada, located in a former gin distillery, is a place with fascinating architecture and contemporary art exhibitions. The buildings, a mix of industrial and modern elements, provide a perfect backdrop for stylish photos. Inside, you‚Äôll find rotating exhibitions by contemporary artists, offering endless opportunities for creative shots.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

sources.snippet: In a former gin distillery from 1910 in the south of Milan, Fondazione Prada has created a unique exhibition space for permanent and temporary art exhibitions. The buildings are Instagrammable ‚Äì such as the new, transparent Podium or the Haunted House, a tower from 1910 covered entirely in gold leaf.
sources.shortName: 23 ultimate Instagrammable places in Milan your teen or tween will absolutely love

places.name: Fondazione Prada

reviews.text:
We enjoyed this museum a lot! Loved the experience of the tower where we started at the top and worked our way down. Italian + English translations available. There were some great works that were super thought provoking. Enjoyed our time here (about 2 hours) and also the cafe desserts were very yummy!

No need to buy tickets in advance. When we went in the end of March, there was no line to get tickets.

It's a renovated distillery turned into a super cool cultural space.
The Haunted House is covered in 200,000 sheets of 24K gold leaf-when the sun hits it, it really shines.
You'll see charcoal-like floors, that golden tower, and a mix of materials that somehow all work together.
It's all about the details and contrast, and it's seriously stunning.

A must visit for contemplating art lovers. This museum area is quite big with many different galleries and buildings. Great mix of different international art exhibitions on a high level. Great industrial yet chic feeling when exploring the museum. Even the toilets are a piece of art here. Would highly recommend.

places.generalDescription: The Bagatti Valsecchi Museum is a 16th-century townhouse located in the heart of downtown Milan. It offers a glimpse into the opulent lifestyle of Milanese families before World War II, with most rooms still showcasing their original interiors. The museum's permanent collection includes handpicked paintings, sculptures, and decorative arts collected by its founders. Visitors can enjoy detailed information in multiple languages throughout the museum.

sources.snippet: Several things make this an especially interesting place to visit. Two brothers in the 19th century spent their lives collecting furnishings and decorative arts to make the interior of their Renaissance palazzo look as it might have appeared originally. Not only will you see a home of that era in a livable state, as opposed to just rooms of display cases and walls of paintings, but you can follow their collecting process through the excellent English signage.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

places.name: Bagatti Valsecchi Museum

reviews.text: An absolutely gorgeous and quick museum (originally a notable family's home). A lot of detail and history within the family and the home. They have an app to download in different languages that you can follow through the home and learn about each room. Really really cool and I definitely recommend for anyone, whether you're a history buff, love architecture and details or just looking for a quick escape from the bustling streets of Milan.
historic house museum in the Montenapoleone district of Milan. The permanent collection mainly contains Italian Renaissance decorative arts, a must visit if you're a medieval/opulent style lover.
It was just plain fantastic. The entire house was a vibe and they really preserved all of the things perfectly. Each room has their own personality and I felt like I went back in time.

places.generalDescription: Santa Maria del Carmine Church, a 15th-century Romanesque church located in the heart of Milan, holds great historical significance. Nestled between the Brera district and Castello Sforzesco, this stunning church features a baroque interior adorned with numerous paintings, frescos, and statues. One of its unique attractions is the Chapel of the Dead, which creates an unusual and slightly eerie atmosphere with its opulent tombs.

sources.snippet: Within walking distance of the Duomo, Brera is one of the most popular and pretty areas of Milan. There, you can find a Baroque church, Santa Maria del Carmine. The facade of the church, overlooking the Piazza del Carmine, was made in 1880 in a rich neo-gothic style.
sources.shortName: Best Instagram Spots in Milan: 10 Incredible Photo Locations

places.name: Chiesa del Carmine

reviews.text: Piazza del Carmine is a charming square that offers a quieter, more authentic slice of Italian life. Surrounded by historic buildings and local cafes, it's a relaxing spot to take in the atmosphere and enjoy a slower pace away from the tourist crowds.

calm place to visit and The Chiesa del Carmine is a serene and beautiful gem tucked away in Milan. Its intricate architecture and peaceful ambiance create a perfect escape from the city's bustle. A delightful spot to reflect and soak in the charm of history and faith.

The Chiesa di Santa Maria del Carmine, located in Milan's Brera district, is a beautiful and historic church dating back to the 15th century. It features a stunning Neo-Gothic facade and a peaceful interior with impressive columns and Renaissance artworks. Notable highlights include the richly decorated Madonna del Carmine Chapel and the Chapel of the Spaniards with works by Camillo Procaccini. It's a calm, spiritual place that combines art, history, and architecture-perfect for a quiet and inspiring visit.

places.address: Piazza del Carmine, 2, 20121 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Nestled in Milan's Brera district, the Brera Botanical Garden is a serene and picturesque oasis established in 1774. This hidden gem boasts flowerbeds, ponds, and an arboretum with centuries-old trees. The garden offers a peaceful setting for photography, with diverse plant collections providing a colorful backdrop. It's an ideal spot for intimate moments or a leisurely stroll amidst rare beauty and timeless atmosphere.

sources.snippet: 4.) Brera Botanical Garden: Located within the district, the Brera Botanical Garden is a hidden gem that offers a peaceful and natural setting for photography. The garden is home to a diverse collection of plants and flowers, providing a serene and colorful backdrop. Photographers can explore the winding paths, capture close-up shots of blooming flowers, or utilize the garden‚Äôs unique landscapes to create stunning compositions with you.
sources.shortName: Brera District & Other Top Photo Spots in Milan

sources.snippet: Located in the hip, trendy, and cool district of Brera (i.e. where all the locals hang out!), the Botanical Gardens are open from Monday through to Saturday and are just one part of a larger complex located around the Brera Palace. Although the Gardens are just 5000 square metres in size, they‚Äôre a perfectly secluded oasis of green, perfect for hanging out with friends and escaping the crowds of Milan.
sources.shortName: Hidden Milan: 10+ Unusual and Secret Spots in Milan (& Map)

places.name: Brera Botanical Garden

reviews.text:
What a charming and lovely garden!
It's between the Pinacoteca di Brera and Palazzo Citterio.  Finding a main entrance was a little tricky. It's not a big garden but enough size to look around and enjoy. You can relax here if you want to have a quiet time from a bustling crowd in Milan.
I expected more, it's a small place and the majority of plants are the basic ones that you can find everywhere. Also not a super quiet place to relax but still worth seeing.

A really small and basic garden, with plants you can find almost everywhere. Good for a 5 minute stroll however there is nothing to come back for. The flowers on the photo are the most interesting part of my visit :)

places.generalDescription: Milano Centrale Railway Station is a grand transportation hub that dates back to the 1930s, featuring glass-topped archways and serving regional and international high-speed services. The station is not only a place for travel but also an architectural marvel with Liberty and Art Deco ornamentation in its main hall and entrances. It offers various shops, a traditional Motta caffe, and a renowned newsstand.

sources.snippet: Milano Centrale is one of the largest and most impressive train stations in Europe, blending Art Deco elements with the monumentalism promoted in Italy during the 1930s. The grand facade and elegant interiors offer numerous photo opportunities for architecture lovers and Instagram enthusiasts. From the imposing front of the building to the rich details inside, this station provides a stunning backdrop for capturing Milan's architectural beauty.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable spots in Milan: 40 photo-worthy locations

places.name: Milano Centrale

reviews.text:
A Majestic and Efficient Hub
Milano Centrale is a magnificent train station, serving as a major hub for both domestic and international travel throughout Europe. The station itself is a grand, architectural marvel, combining a functional transport hub with an aesthetically pleasing design.
Inside, you'll find a wide variety of food shops and restaurants, as well as a large number of self-service ticket machines for convenience. Navigating the station is simple, as the platform information is clear and easily accessible. The station is well-equipped for all travelers, with both escalators and stairs connecting the different levels.
To access the toilets like other places in Europe,  pay 01 Euro. Toilets are clean.
Trains to many destinations within and outside Italy. Big station with a lot of people that makes it chaotic. Beautiful architecture and adequate signs.

Great train station with many restaurant and shop options. The only issue is that the elevators are not easy to spot, but once you find them it's easier to move around while having children/strollers. There are still some renovations at this moment but it's ok.

places.address: Piazza Duca d'Aosta, 1, 20124 Milano MI, Italy

places.generalDescription: Nestled near Porta Ticinese, the Basilica di Sant'Eustorgio is a captivating Romanesque-style Catholic church steeped in history. Founded in the 4th century and later reconstructed in the 19th century, this architectural gem has long been a significant pilgrimage site. It was believed to house the relics of the Three Magi, brought from Constantinople by Saint Eustorgius himself.

sources.snippet: The Romanesque Basilica of Sant'Eustorgio was built in the 12th and 13th centuries, and its fine campanile was added a century later. The facade was not added until 1863. Look beyond the choir to find the Cappella Portinari, by Michelozzo in 1462-68, one of the earliest examples of Renaissance architecture.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions & Things to Do in Milan

places.name: Basilica di Sant'Eustorgio

reviews.text: This is an amazing structure and a must see location for any trip to Milan.  The feeling of the history of this place is awe inspiring.  Also, the staff is very informed and very helpful in illuminating the depth of the experience.
It's a peaceful and classic church that you definitely should visit while in Milan!

A significant example of late 4th-century early Christian architecture, the basilica has been an important pilgrimage site since the Roman Empire. Originally known as Basilica Trium Magorum, it was believed to house the relics of the Three Magi. The first church was founded around 344, and by the late 4th century, the relics of the Magi were reportedly enshrined here, prompting the change in dedication. From the 13th century onward, the basilica became associated with the Dominican Order and underwent significant expansion. One of its most notable features is the Portinari Chapel, built between 1462 and 1468. In the 19th century, the church's fa√ßade was restored in a Neo-Romanesque style.
